title.narrative: Value addition of Milk to Develop Dairy Processing Capacity and Rural Entrepreneurship

description.narrative: The longer term impact will be on food security and poverty levels of communities in South Sudan where OPEN is active. Medium term impact is the improved capacity of OPEN to guide farmers in improving their food security and income levels. The outcome of the TMT will be a workforce of OPEN able to guide farmers in their working area in improving their dairy production improving the food security and income levels of OPEN farmer target groups. Concrete outputs are: -15 trained extension workers, including 8 females, competent to train local farmers in improving dairy production and develop farmer training programs targeting male as well as female farmers. -Farmer training programs -Improved farmer training monitoring systems

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please **For TMT+:** Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value: Almost the entire team of trainers/ extension workers currently active for PLYC in agricultural/ livestock development programs participated in the training. Working in very difficult, challenging and sometimes dangerous conditions extension staff of PLYC is involved in the implementation of various livestock development programs. PLYC staff, mainly young graduates with various educational background, lack a lot of knowledge, skills and experience necessary for proper implementation of agricultural/ livestock programs including experience in the technical aspects of analysing dairy value chains and setting up and managing a small scale commercial dairy farms. During the training it became quickly clear that every topic and the approach used to transfer knowledge and skills were “eye openers” to all participants. For most it was also a special experience to work in teams comprising of men and women on assignments. It was clear that mixed teams in this kind of work has great advantages in order to address the needs of male and female small holder farmers. At the end of the training all participants informed the trainers that their way of working in the future would change completely after this training. During the Module on dairy value chain analysis and development students were made aware of the concept of (dairy) value chains. They are able to describe and analyze existing dairy value chains, the role of actors, service providers, administration(s) and policies (local, national and international). They are able to link these issues to their own situation. Attention was also given to quality control in the Dairy Value Chain and sensoric evaluation of dairy products. Participants are enthusiastic about the Value Chain concept, however, they understand that small holder farmer can only participate successfully in value chains if they have the basic knowledge and skills to run their farm as a business. During the Dairy Farm Management Module the principles of dairy farm economics, management and entrepreneurship were explained and exercised. Use of key performance indicators for assessing/ analysing the technical and financial performance were explained and used in various, initial theoretical, exercises. Various categories of dairy farmers were visited (small scale, emerging farmers, commercial farmers, male as well as female farmers) and students were assigned to analyse the technical as well as financial performance of these farms in groups and develop plans for improvement of the technical as well as the financial performance based on their observations and information collected from the farmers during the visits. Also gender related issues were included in the assignment. Each group was assigned a specific dairy farm for their assignment and present their findings and recommendations. Also attention was given to dairy cattle nutrition management, young stock rearing, health management, fertility management and housing. In the last Module attention was given to “Training of Trainers” topics. Principles of competence based learning, developing short training programs for farmers/farm workers (in his/her area of expertise), developing a lesson plan (one training session) and implementation of the lesson plan developed. At the end of week 3 student were given the assignment to develop a short farmer training program in a step wise approach (in groups) which was monitored by Aeres. In week 4 feedback was provided to the work done and individual training performance assessed. During the evaluation of the Course all participants acknowledged that they had learned very much and that their way of training of emerging young commercial dairy farmers would change and improve a lot. Greenhouse gas emissions on dairy farms received special attention during the Course. Awareness was raised that particularly in Asia GHG emissions per kg milk are very high due to the low efficiency and poor quality of feed available to dairy animals. Measures to mitigate the impact of climate change and measures to reduce GHG emissions on dairy farms were discussed thoroughly. Ideas have been used by the participants and they intend to incorporate this information into their own curricula over time. Given the very low level of knowledge of local farmers and the very low level of development of the dairy sector in the working area of PLYC it is currently not the most pressing issue. The training has certainly contributed to the institutional capacity in curriculum development, technical knowledge and skills and M&E system of training programs. Accreditation systems were briefly touched upon (the system in place by Aeres (NVAO)was explained). PLYC was advised to establish contacts with the Agricultural University in Faisalabad for establishing a system for accreditation of their training programs. For gender see the output below. All of the above will certainly have an impact in the way trainees/ PLYC will develop and implement training programs in the future. A total of 7 female extension workers participated fully in the training and discussions, participating side by side with their male colleagues as equals. Various training sessions and exercises involving gender issues were included in the training raising awareness. In the training of trainers Module attention was given on how to develop curricula which were gender sensitive. Trainees represented various ethnic groups and age varied from 22 to 35 years.

actual.value: During the training it became quickly clear that every topic and the approach used to transfer knowledge and skills were “eye openers” to all participants. At the end of the training all participants informed the trainers that their way of working in the future would change completely after this training. During the evaluation of the Course all participants acknowledged that they had learned very much and that their way of training of emerging young commercial dairy farmers would change and improve a lot.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Gender and Value Chains was an important issue during the course. Through exercises they were made aware of role of gender in different areas of the chain realizing the inequality between different groups and the need to change this. The participants are aware of the gender (in)sensitivity of their own organization. Participants were assigned to discuss gender related issues with dairy farm managers having an impact on the performance of their dairy farms during visits of dairy farms during the Module on dairy farm management and farm economics. Participants were made aware about gender while developing lesson plans during the third module and how to make training programs gender sensitive. In total 7 female trainers/ extension workers participated in the training. Various training sessions and exercises involving gender issues were included in the training raising awareness. In the training of trainers Module attention was given on how to develop curricula which were gender sensitive.
